title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MIAMI, FL — March 12, 1997 — In the annals of NBA history, some performances transcend the final score and become the story itself. Wednesday night was one of those nights, as Alonzo Mourning authored a legendary chapter, single-handedly dismantling the Washington Bullets in a 103-92 Miami Heat victory.

From the opening tip, it was clear this was Mourning’s domain. The Bullets had no answer for the Heat center, who operated with a ferocious and unstoppable rhythm. He was a force of nature in the paint, converting powerful post moves and facing little resistance from the Washington defense. By the final buzzer, the stat sheet told a staggering tale: a career-high and franchise-record 50 points on a hyper-efficient 21-of-29 shooting from the field.

But Mourning was not merely a scorer; he was a destroyer of entire game plans. He complemented his historic offensive outburst with 12 rebounds, completing a dominant double-double that underscored his complete control of the interior. Defensively, he was an imposing fortress, swatting away 5 Bullet shots and altering countless others, rendering Washington’s drives to the basket an exercise in futility.

While Tim Hardaway provided crucial support with 18 points and 9 assists, and Walt Williams added 12 points, this night belonged to one man. The Bullets, led by 24 points from Calbert Cheaney, simply watched as Mourning put on a masterclass.

In the end, the 11-point margin of victory was a mere footnote. The real story was the eruption of a superstar, as Alonzo Mourning’s 50-point tour de force cemented a night that would be remembered not for who won, but for how one colossal performance made it so.
